seg.seg: ... the great damage of the fathers ...
... Thirst [is] the source of all sufferings and attachments ...
... the worthy one perceived the [four] truths [and] reached the fi(rst) level ...
... Arhathood. [24d] To eat alms (from somewhere else) ...
... also like the wound of pus [attracts] flies. Give up [pl.] the ...
... the fivefold pleasures have [not] been able to, [so] without disappearance...
... exchanged by the god Viśvakarma [in the divine shape (?)] ...
... To him spoke the Omniscient: Not Nanda ...
... to let him become (believing) he then proclaimed this strophe to him ...
... he indeed perceived this: Truly, with regard to myself ...
... take me as a lay member, (to be) [my] lifelong shelter ...
... he spoke often about the damages of the (pleasures), he spoke [whole] sections ...
... The Buddha then told an earlier (incident) of these monks ...
... he was out of town at that time. (To the) Pratyekabuddha came ...
... (in the) countries, in the town Dantapura. The town ...

p.note: The 4 x 15-syllable-metre apparently used in this fragment is already known to us from the second part of the Mārgavarga (XII), cf. - . This fragment here, however, cannot be part of the latter, since the content here does not match with that of , which shows the same strophe numbers. The same metre, however, was also used in the chapter dealing with the Cittavarga (XXXI), see : A1-3, 72ff., and the agreement of b2 tek\ śarsa auspa : ñiś palkormeṃ with : A1b4 klyauṣa nande ñäś ṣarmmeṃ pudñäkte ślokanma weña is rather astounding. But in A1b4 this is already strophe 81, whereas a4 in this text has the strophe number 24. Due to the scantiness of the fragment, which, after all, has preserved only a single strophe number, not even recto and verso side can be identified with any certainty; and in the translation a lot of things remain doubtful.

General remarks

The 4 x 15-syllable-metre apparently used in this fragment is already known to us from the second part of the Mārgavarga (XII), cf. [[THT 28]] - [[THT 30]]. But in A1b4 this is already strophe 81, whereas a4 in this text has the strophe number 24. Due to the scantiness of the fragment, which, after all, has preserved only a single strophe number, not even recto and verso side can be identified with any certainty; and in the translation a lot of things remain doubtful.
